At that time, how did the World-Honored One speak of the path? When speaking of the path, it is like
the king's great road, called the king's road, and the stars are called the road of the stars.

This path is also like this. Those who reach nirvÄá¹‡a call it the road to nirvÄá¹‡a. That is the place of equal views, equal intentions, equal speech, and equal livelihood without error, equal skillful means without leakage, equal mindfulness immeasurable, and equal samÄdhi with unchanging form.

Depending on those various forms, there is no lust or defilement, and afflictions are forever eradicated without arising. There is no attachment to form or various thorns. In order to extinguish desire and attachment, there is also no mud. In order to eliminate wrong views, equal views are fully possessed, and in order to equally extinguish afflictions, they are forever eradicated without arising again.

Because of that subtle fruit, various meanings are manifested. In order to eliminate hopes, there are no various thoughts. In order to seek liberation and happiness, various fruits are accomplished. Because of the essential non-attachment, the name and form are equally liberated. Because of wandering there, it is said to be the path, without a second. All attain that ultimate truth, and the cause is one. The vow of one's own mind is called entry.

At that time, the World-Honored One used the foremost eloquence to understand the path. Being able to awaken by oneself, one is not destroyed. The superior karma is done without confusion. Having already attained the fruits and rewards of all wholesome roots, one is able to awaken those beings and then explain this path to lead them to the unconditioned.
Then, he spoke this verse:
The various types of beings who arise have the path of the sweet dew Dharma.
The Buddha has these merits, foremost in the world.
I have now attained myself, with pure precepts complete.
I bow my head to the one who speaks for the sake of others.

At that time, the World-Honored One knew that Angulimala was now ready to be transformed. At that time, there were no evil friends or discussions. After awakening, he went to the road, where there was only one person left, with blood filling the road. People all knew that flying crows and vultures were eating everywhere.
At that time, Angulimala's movements were like a swift wind. When he raised his foot, the herds of deer and flying birds were all frightened and ran away.

At that time, Angulimala looked around in the Jeta Grove, but saw nothing. He only saw the World-Honored One, upright and incomparably purple-gold colored, skillfully acting without bending at the waist, with a body extremely soft and fine, walking in an orderly manner, running with all his might, chasing after the Tathagata.
At that time, the World-Honored One did not change his old ways and he could not catch up.
At that time, the World-Honored One transformed the ground into pits and ditches with thorns, and for this reason he could not catch up.
Some say, Because he stepped on the ground with his feet, that is why he could not reach the World-Honored One.
Some say, The transformation body has no form and four elements, and eye consciousness cannot grasp it.
Some say, The Buddha's merits are inconceivable.

However, Angulimala's strength was like a rampaging elephant that no one could withstand, but the Buddha's power is inconceivable. Even if there were billions of powerful beings like the divine dragon Narayana, they still could not approach the Tathagata.
At that time, Angulimala then praised, saying:
I see this unprecedented sight.
He then addressed the World-Honored One, saying:
This mind is extremely wonderful and special.
He then had no more thoughts of anger or harm.
He thought like this:
Whose kindness and virtue is this?
This must be a divine person.
Just like this evil world, I have returned to this beauty, just like a famine, and I also give rise to loving thoughts.
But I cannot reach it. This must be a good spiritual friend.
Now I am exhausted and will stay.
He spoke to the World-Honored One from afar, saying:
For my sake, what the world rarely sees or hears,
I now also see your virtue, please stay for a while.
The World-Honored One said:
You yourself do not stay, yet you say I should stay.
Then Aá¹…gulimÄla said to the World-Honored One:
The Å›ramaá¹‡a himself does not stay, I say to stay but do not stay.
Why do I not stay?
Please explain in detail, World-Honored One.
At that time, the World-Honored One said:
Absence of evil is staying, upholding precepts and protecting people are long-lasting,
Like the disciples of KÄÅ›yapa, therefore you do not stay.
He originally had few evils, which were completely extinguished. Blood flowed and stained his body. He then unsheathed his sword and placed it to one side. He said to the World-Honored One:
The teacher is now my protector, encountering this holy teacher,
I seek to be his disciple, not violating the teacher's precepts.
At that time, the World-Honored One said this:
Welcome, bhiká¹£us!
And spoke this verse:
Just like the water of the great ocean, it also gives rise to smoke and fire,
Those who have not yet been subdued, should now be transformed by me.
There are also those who are well subdued, pure and liberated,
They are also my disciples, thus not accepting existence.
Those who see it all fear it, as well as the various demons and spirits,
In the abodes of these demons and spirits, the most excellent one enters there.

At that time, the ghost Alobha heard what the ghost KumbhÄ«ra said, and his anger flared up, his complexion changed, the fire of anger arose, his eyes were like red copper, his voice thundered, and he shook his head and bit his lip, shaking his body, and said:
I also do not see any people in the world who can come to my dwelling place.
He harbored such doubts:
Why did that person come to me?
The ghosts named BhadrapÄla and Liheyamozhi, who were the leaders of the two good ones, said to the great ghost:
Do not speak like that. The World-Honored Buddha is able to subdue those who have not been subdued, able to bring peace to sentient beings and attain the unsurpassed path, and protect all beings.
Such a field of blessings is not appropriate. Your coarse words and evil speech are not appropriate.
At that time, his anger flared up even more than before.

At that time, the demon king Arapachi's breath was like a raging fire, his gaze was extremely fierce, and he abandoned the demon realm. Enveloped by anger, his body was extremely dark, his complexion changed, and he was not the same as usual. Four fangs protruded from his mouth, his hair was yellow like gold, and he crossed his arms up and down. Human blood stained his body, all wet and not dry. He wore a lion skin, an elephant skin, and a yak skin, with a large flower garland like a great raging fire. He held a sword and shield in his hands, and walked while striking the ground, destroying mountains and moving mountain forests, uprooting trees.

He either created a great cloud that obscured the great light, sprinkled water in the sky with a sound like thunder, and then went to his dwelling place to harm the World-Honored One, or burned various trees, changing their colors. He held a discus, thunder, lightning, and hail.
In this way, with anger, he observed the TathÄgata and created various transformations, seeking an opportunity to harm the TathÄgata.
At that time, the Buddha spoke this verse:
Sentient beings have thoughts of fear, but my resolve does not waver.
Now that I have attained the Dharma of liberation, I have no fearful thoughts.
I am not afraid of fire when in a fire, nor am I afraid of water.
How can those who harbor evil thoughts harm me?

At that time, the ghost Arapati heard the World-Honored One's words, and immediately gave up his thoughts and was unable to destroy [the Buddha]. In that frightening place, where people do not go, he then rained hail upon the Tathagata, but none of it fell to the ground, each scattering elsewhere. Some that fell on the Tathagata's body all transformed into celestial mandara flowers.
At that time, the king of ghosts saw this power and was amazed. He then gave rise to a joyful mind and said to the Tathagata:
Quickly come out.
Monk!
The World-Honored One then came out.
At that time, the ghost wanted to test the World-Honored One, and said this:
Go back in, monk!
However, the World-Honored One, with no resentment in his mind, went to that place.
In this way, up to three times, explained in detail as in the sutra.
Then the World-Honored One spoke this verse:
Neither Shakra nor the Brahma gods can move a single hair of mine,
Let alone your strength now, able to harm me?
You should now abandon anger, and if you have doubts, ask at any time,
Whatever uncertainties you have, I will explain them one by one.
At that time, the ghost then asked this question:
What kind of person is the best?
Explained in detail as in the sutra.
At that time, in the present life, he gave rise to a joyful mind towards the Tathagata and spoke this verse:
Never before have I seen such a Å›ramaá¹‡a as this,
Who can abandon the great ocean and go to the water in a cow's hoofprint?
He should speak like this for the sake of my body.
Who would not enjoy this taste and abandon the nectar?
Like a strong man who is swept away by the water,
Already rescued from the perilous situation, placed on the shore of the unconditioned.
Good form is incomparable, observed by the wise,
Those who possess that meaning are able to expound this Dharma.
From now on I take refuge in the Buddha, the Three Jewels are the most honored,
The reason for making a vow is to be able to deliver all.

Thus, the five great earth spirits of the realm of Magadha, who dwell in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, protect the people with great power and protection, with flourishing vehicles and a fertile land. The sages and people all dwell there without equal, eating like nectar, with the three matters subtle and without many troubles, like the Nandana Garden of the gods.

At that time, the World-Honored Buddha was unsurpassed. Devadatta always harbored anger towards the World-Honored One without rest. His actions were unlawful. Because of this anger, he went up Mount Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a, where the gardens were flourishing, the trees were luxuriant, and the springs were pure. He held a rock in his hand, intending to throw it at the TathÄgata, and then released the rock.
At that time, the rock had no sentient thoughts, yet it was able to hold itself and gradually fall to the ground.

Devadatta had right and wrong meanings. Various ghosts and spirits held the rock, wanting it not to fall. The KimbÄ«ra ghost resided on Mount Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a. When the rock was about to fall due to its own power, it gave rise to this thought:
Although this is evil karma, we yaká¹£as should accomplish this matter with this body, and also cause the World-Honored One to experience hundreds of thousands of pleasures. If we can do this matter,
it then spoke this verse:
The mind is pure without blemish, giving rise to various meanings,
I will now sink this body, without harming the most excellent one.

At that time Devadatta then released a stone towards the TathÄgata. At that time on the mountain, the ghost immediately used his hand to catch the stone. There was a piece of broken stone that fell towards the TathÄgata. He received this retribution and blood flowed from his toe. Devadatta received immeasurable offenses. Due to this retribution, he would enter hell.

At that time when the stone fell to the ground, the thirty-three celestials scattered flowers in offering, using emptiness liberation. At that time the scattered flowers filled the sky. In the transformation lecture hall of the thirty-three celestials, the tree of the continent, the Buddha's light shone far, without arrogance, compassionately loving sentient beings.
At that time, when the brÄhmaá¹‡a PÄrÄÅ›arya scolded the World-Honored One with five hundred matters, the bhiká¹£us such as ÅšÄriputra and PÅ«rá¹‡a sighed in praise of the TathÄgata.
At that time, the TathÄgata, whether reviled or insulted, did not become displeased. If further praised and lauded, he did not become delighted.
At that time, he then spoke this verse:
The mind does not waver in the face of suffering, like Mount Sumeru unmoving,
The mind is very firm, therefore I bow to the divine sage.
For the sake of other sentient beings, the merit is immeasurable,
Like a father loves his child, who would not bow to him?

Once I heard this: The World-Honored One was in the realm of Magadha. At that time, the World-Honored One, endowed with immeasurable merits, at mealtime put on his robe and took his bowl, surrounded by the great assembly, his faculties complete, observing his own body without any disturbance, walking in an orderly manner without haste, leading the countless bhiká¹£us to go there.

At that time, the king of Magadha had an elephant named DhanapÄla, with an extremely handsome appearance, three humps on its head, a clear and penetrating voice, and an intention to go wherever it wished, difficult to control. If it heard a strange sound, it would become angry. If it saw its own shadow, it would also become angry. No one could stand in front of it. It could go wherever it wanted. If it fought, it would not damage its strength or decrease it.

At that time, the World-Honored One entered the city, with moats, towers, and ramparts all complete, and the people were prosperous. Some were sorrowful, some were joyful, fearing to harm the TathÄgata but wanting to get close to the TathÄgata.
At that time, Devadatta made the young elephant drunk and released it.
At that time, after Devadatta released the elephant, he spoke this verse:ğŸ”½Claiming to have great strength,
And the ten powers of the body,ğŸ”½Today they have gathered here,
And will all be destroyed by it.
At that time, the World-Honored One, fearless, spoke this verse:
I have a thousand irobas, none can defeat me,
how much less can this small insect harm the supreme among humans?
At that time, I had no thoughts and spoke this verse:
Without the power of desire, sentient beings have a desirous mind,
to eliminate this desire and retribution, I also do not harbor confusion.
Again, this verse was spoken:
Although I am now destroyed, the great elephant is very firm,
I now subdue him, unsurpassed in the entire world.

At that time, DhandapÄla carefully looked at the TathÄgata's form, his complexion was extremely dark, he saw the elephant wagging its tail, its body upright, all who saw it were terrified, and it ran towards the TathÄgata.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us, receiving the TathÄgata's compassionate power, in accordance with the TathÄgata's instructions, avoided the evil elephant and each fled far from the TathÄgata's place. Only Venerable Ä€nanda remained behind the TathÄgata, having been with the TathÄgata for countless lifetimes, not sparing his own life and also not abandoning the TathÄgata.
At that time, the elephant DÄnapatra, with the fire of anger burning his body, wanted to harm the TathÄgata. At that time, the fire of anger gradually subsided, as explained in detail in the sÅ«tra.

At that time, with the incomparably subtle wheel-mark on his hand, the TathÄgata raised his hand and placed it on the elephant's head, with a mind of compassion and no anger. Hearing the TathÄgata's words, the elephant immediately wept and placed its head on the TathÄgata's feet, licking the feet with its tongue, unable to move.
At that time, the elephant became fearful, its body losing strength and power, and it involuntarily defecated and urinated.
Then the World-Honored One, with these sages, spoke this verse:
Without desire or arrogance, the World-Honored One is free from these defilements.
When compassion arises, one will surely be born in the heavens.
At that time, the World-Honored One, with this sound, was doubly joyful and with a pleasant countenance. He touched the TathÄgata's feet with his forehead and nose and returned to his own country.
The multitude of people saw this unprecedented event, with the elephant subdued. They were joyful and without fear in their hearts, and all had faith and joy in the TathÄgata.
At that time, he spoke this verse:
Like a mountain that cannot be moved, how much less can anger prevail?
By conquering that enemy, it is like the IrÄma dragon.
Having such virtues, with power and might unmatched,
The hero-lion among men, all will come to pay homage.
Such a type of being, without an ignorant mind,
Subduing the names of the three realms, the enlightened mind is unequaled.
Thus, among sentient beings, there are also afflictions of anger,
But their intentions and natures are all at rest, firmly established and widely known.
Adorned with wisdom, the mind is pure and unattached,
Endowed with the ten powers, therefore one should bow one's head.

At that time, the king was like the moon in the sky without any dust, his mind at peace and all affairs accomplished. The seven sages were all adorned without any defilements, and the stars adorned themselves like a celestial elephant. Wherever he went, clouds followed behind him, and various adornments embellished his body.

Having heard this, he was like a divine elephant roaming about, and the precious treasures were also free from doubt. The four divisions of the army and the people surrounded him on their own, and on that elephant, he raised the elephant's trunk in reverence.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha. Wishing to see the TathÄgata, he went to where the World-Honored One was.
At that time, the World-Honored One saw that the king had come out in a short while, surrounded by countless people. The king then had this thought:
Since I have come from afar, I should protect myself.
Having had this thought, he immediately told JÄ«vaka, and upon seeing him, he said these words:
Are you not going to revive me?

At that time, in a short while, the king's complexion became incomparably handsome, surpassing that of others. The flowers and fruits were luxuriant, and there was no dust. The three parts were complete, like a bee king. The sound was not good. In that garden, the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha surrounded him in front and back. Coming from afar, he wanted to see the TathÄgata. Having seen him, he repeatedly looked at JÄ«vaka and said to him:
What are those things in the middle?
At that time, JÄ«vaka replied to the king, saying:
They are called flesh-topped knots.
At that time, the king asked again:
Are they naturally so?
Or are they not natural?ğŸ”½JÄ«vaka said to the king:
Your Majesty!
The fruits of past actions, not what is created now.
The king replied:
What fruits are used to form a bodhisattva?
In the past life, when the bodhisattva was conceived, the past actions and the past body were used.
The sutra explains in detail.
At that time, the king spoke this verse:
Just like the various kinds of light from the sun,
The ushnisha is unsurpassed, let alone the other marks.
The face is already peaceful and joyful, the benevolent one is not timid,
Having emitted this light, it shines through the ten directions.
At that time, the king went to where the Buddha was. The Buddha told Jivaka:
How can you say this?
Jivaka said to the king:
In this world, those who can subdue arrogance will attain nobility and wealth, while those who are arrogant will be born in a lowly place.
At that time, the king immediately calmed down and contemplated these words. He then said:
This is a field of merit. Should I engage in this practice?
How can I, who am so noble and revered, bow to him?
He has no ornaments, while I am wearing the king's robe and crown.
Although that person is upright and has a peaceful mind, endowed with all the characteristics without any ugliness, his appearance is extremely subtle, like a mountain that cannot be moved.

He then went to the gate, his mind filled with joy and his hair standing on end. Because of his determination to leave the householder's life, he appeared without any signs of desire. He bowed his head to the World-Honored One's feet and said:
Just as the World-Honored One has such appearance, his mind and thoughts are correct and fully accomplished. May the Buddha and the assembly of monks, as well as my son Udayabhadras, be like this.
He then asked about the meaning of this and spoke with joy, also reciting this verse:
Just as the ocean has no boundaries, when the wind blows the water moves,
The Sage cannot be moved, now observing the supreme among humans,
Shakra comes to pay homage, as well as the assembly of Brahma gods,
I will now revere and take refuge in the World-Honored One.

At that time, the brahmin Jatila Sunirmita, like a pure white flower riding in a horse-drawn carriage, surrounded by a multitude of disciples, left the city of Shravasti, wishing to test the Tathagata. He went by carriage as far as the carriage could go, then got down and entered the garden on foot. He gradually discussed with the Tathagata and sat to one side.

At that time, the place where the World-Honored One was staying, there was nothing to be seen, seeing the Tathagata's complexion was extremely subtle and wonderful, there was none equal to him, and also no cowardice, having the marks of a wheel-turning sage king, seeing this body, the eyes observing and knowing such dharmas, like the World-Honored One's Dharma is very profound and subtle, the pure practice also has no place, having such great merit and virtue, praised and spoken by the wise, desire and love have no firmness and also no falsehood.
At that time, the brahman then asked this question:
How does the Venerable know for himself that he practices pure conduct?
Is it not practicing pure conduct?
Is it to erect the faculties by oneself?
Knowing it is difficult to measure.
At that time, the World-Honored One said:
If one speaks like this, it is also not leaking, it is not without power, and also without various practices, extremely pure, without blemish or defilement, practicing pure conduct.
If someone speaks to us like this, saying this, what is the meaning of this?
As extensively explained in the sutra.
At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a JÄtiÅ›Å«ra asked the World-Honored One again:ğŸ”½What is meant by 'defect'?
What is meant by 'leakage'?
What is meant by 'practice'?
What is meant by 'not being without power'?
What is meant by 'the most pure and incomparable practice of all practices'?
At that time, the World-Honored One said:

Here, brÄhmaá¹‡a, one should practice this. If one seeks love and pleasure, if there is a practitioner who personally experiences suffering and happiness, observing the eyes and forms, such a practitioner should first seek the practice in this way. If thoughts and attachments arise, that is called a defect. Counting those many things is called leakage. What is perceived by the mind is called not being without power. The mind is without defilements, yet it runs and flows among them, giving rise to impure thoughts. Because of this, it is called the defilement of the practice.
As extensively explained in the sutra.

The brahmin sees in me a body covered by skin, a mass of impurities, and chooses to see the body. My desire for form is already exhausted. Should I then observe the eye with the eye and the form with the form?
However, brahmin, I observe that there is no more activity in feeling, how could there be feeling?
I desire to be attached to feeling and experience this smoothness. However, brahmin, I observe that everything is impermanent. How could I desire to have an attached mind that is not exhausted?
If, brahmin, I do not observe these dharmas, whether male or female, all are discriminated. How could I then give rise to thoughts of female desire and be attached to them?
If, brahmin, there is no thought of male desire, and one is not in accord with the thought of female, but directly gives rise to the thought of desire?
Just as, brahmin, there is a limited extent from which one can attain the bliss of liberation, how could one then remember the original actions one has created?

Then the brÄhmaá¹‡as and those who give rise to non-meaningful things, wishing to rescue and deliver from suffering, left the household life to study the path. With this vow, they cultivated the holy life. There were seven things that were not in accord with the holy life, without deficiency or leakage, and also without various practices.
Explained in detail as in the sÅ«tra.
If there are brÄhmaá¹‡as and sentient beings who have confused thoughts and attachments, not free from desire, how should one contemplate those sentient beings?
All those who have pure thoughts and attachments to this body, the internal foul-smelling places, all desires are exhausted.
Just as a brÄhmaá¹‡a mixes water and milk, just as there is this milk, so is the union of desire.
One should observe in this way, the sinews and bones are connected, the internal foul-smelling impurities, what is there to crave?
Just as a brÄhmaá¹‡a first gives a sweet taste to a newborn baby to put in its mouth, and then makes it drink bitter things.

It is the same with this. When one unites and gives rise to thoughts of desire, one is able to endure the various hundreds of aspects of the suffering of desire, just like a newly dead calf. When one observes its skin and obtains much milk, it is like a newly born calf that dies. One takes its skin and ferments it with grass, making it into the shape of a living calf, and places it in front of its mother.
The mother thinks that the calf is alive, so her milk does not dry up.

It is the same with this. When one transcends the various dead objects and so forth, and observes their appearance, one gives rise to thoughts of defilement, just like a hungry and thirsty brahmin who dreams of eating delicious food and drink, and then joyfully leaps up, yet that person has nothing to eat.

It is the same with this. The foolish people who are attached to desire are no different from that dream. When they unite and give rise to thoughts, yet that person actually has no good conduct, whether male or female or with various changes.
Then he spoke this verse:
This is not the true Dharma. How can one crave desire and anger?
Brahmin, you should observe well, the root of suffering is difficult to uproot?
The most important thing is to be close to the path, and to cut off the mind of desire,
The eightfold noble path, thus up to a good place.
At that time, the five people encountered the Tathagata, and upon seeing him, they said to each other:

The person who is coming here has not accomplished what he originally set out to do. He has seen and heard much, and thinks whatever he wants without any difficulty. He has undergone various hardships and is still confused and has not attained the Way.
Explained in detail as in the sutra.
At that time, the World-Honored One had this thought:
I pity this foolish and deluded person who has made a restriction for himself. That restriction is to have no respectful mind towards the Tathagata.
At that time, the World-Honored One had already arrived where that person was, and sat on the pure ground, wanting to cure the illness caused by the bonds.
At that time, the Buddha said to the five people:
Why did you say that?
They took turns begging for food and explaining the profound Dharma.
At that time, the five people did not accept the teachings, and this Dharma was very painful to realize.
At that time, they said to the World-Honored One:

You originally practiced austerities for six years, eating only one sesame seed and one grain of rice a day, yet you still did not attain the Way. How much less so now, speaking of attaining the Way at will, following your heart and mouth?
Eating delicious food and drink, wearing precious clothes, indulging in whatever you desire and nourishing your body.
At that time, the World-Honored One said:
How do you, bhiká¹£us, see the TathÄgata's appearance as having changed?
The faculties and mind are tranquil, and the facial features are upright. Is the current appearance and countenance any different from the original complexion?
That realm is past.
They replied:
It is upright now, without compare.
The World-Honored One said:
If you had not originally obtained this nectar, who would have obtained the nectar in this trichiliocosm?
I have also heard that the devas and asuras obtain nectar at the bottom of the great ocean and Mount Sumeru.

It is the same here. In this trichiliocosm, with a courageous mind, I have obtained the taste of the nectar of wisdom. This is extremely wonderful and special, something the world has never seen before. The practice of a hundred thousand kalpas, the cessation of the mind, is the most wonderful. Far from form and liberation, the taste of nectar is very profound. For the sake of those beings, I will explain the Dharma. With great patience and effort, I have never declined. For the sake of all afflictions, I do not give rise to dust and defilements. In order to open the wisdom of the mind, I dwell in the mother's womb. Because of this birth and death, I will ultimately reach its source.

Because of non-extinction, it cannot be exhausted. Because of permanence, the Dharma is not lacking. Because of the absence of sorrow and distress, it is joy. In order to extinguish the bonds, I will not create new ones. The great sages praise and admire me, and my assembly is accomplished. However, what I practice is hard work. For the sake of all living beings, I will now explain the Dharma.

At that time, the World-Honored One's perfect light was seven feet, his countenance was like Mount Sumeru, he was revered by the three periods of time, and the teachings of the Omniscient One were unobstructed:
Thus, bhiká¹£us, this is called the basis of suffering, and one who has accomplished the three knowledges.
It is explained in detail as in the sÅ«tras.
Praised by gods and humans, his light is inexhaustible, and at that time, the sun's eclipse does not appear.

Moreover, this person, or wearing subtle garments, comes to the TathÄgata, or wearing heavenly garments, comes to the TathÄgata, all letting down heavenly crowns of various colors, or necklaces falling to the ground, hungering and thirsting for the World-Honored One's nectar.
At that time, he immediately spoke this verse:
The World-Honored One is also unborn, benefiting the multitudes of gods and humans,
Like eating the taste of nectar, ultimately without the suffering of hunger and thirst.
Today, the one with ten powers, when born, the world praises,
They will drink the deep flavor of the Dharma and have already reached the realm of liberation.
At that time, the assembly contemplated the noble truth of suffering, the first suffering of accepting the womb, from where does it arise?
Permanently dwelling in the dark netherworld, not seeing the light, for this reason, birth is the greatest suffering.
Contemplating this characteristic of suffering, birth is the long suffering, unable to endure the long suffering of karma, when the muscles and strength are formed, there is hope for suffering;
The mind is not content, wanting to seek but not obtaining is suffering;
